awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Nanophotonics Enabled Solar Membrane Distillation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is addressing the increasing demand for sustainable water purification and cost-effective phase separation with an energy-efficient, economical, portable and scalable solution. More than a billion people around the world lack access to clean drinking water. Most of the existing technologies for water purification and phase separation mainly use energy from conventional fuels increasing their operating cost and limiting their application. The proposed technology of Nanophotonics-enabled Solar Membrane Distillation (NESMD) uses solar energy to vaporize water and potentially other liquids of interest. NESMD system is energy-efficient, portable and can be scaled in size making it suitable for household, commercial and industrial water purification. Cost-effective phase separation with NESMD can be attractive for petroleum and related industries as well.

This I-Corps project focuses on electricity-free water purification and phase separation. Nanophotonics-enabled Solar Membrane Distillation (NESMD) system consists of a polymer membrane coated with light-absorbing carbon-based nanomaterials which efficiently absorb incident sunlight. The capability of converting light into heat within a thin layer on top of a semipermeable membrane allows an efficient local conversion of liquid to its vapor phase. This membrane can be used in contact with saline/polluted water or a mixture of organic solvents allowing the heat from the absorbed sunlight to induce vaporization through the membrane separating the liquid of interest from non-volatile components such as salts, heavy metals, bacteria or other liquids. Proof-of-concept lab-scale studies of the NESMD system show efficient water purification with more than 99.5% salt rejection. Through this I-Corps project the team wants to further assess and investigate the value of this technology for water purification and phase separation market.

por.por_cntn:
Broader impact: The broader impact of this project is the demonstration of the need for a sustainable technology to treat high salinity water though practical interviews with potential end users, customers and influencers. Development of a sustainable, low-cost, high throughput desalination technology will help address the disposal of millions of gallons of high salinity waste produced by Oil & Gas industry, desalination plants and brackish underground reservoirs providing additional fresh water resource for agriculture, drinking and other use.  

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of this project is finding specific criterion for successful application new desalination technologies to treat high salinity water in terms of cost, salinity levels, and amount of water to be handled per day. These findings will be helpful in development of new desalination systems with focus on converting high salinity waste from Oil & Gas industries, desalination plants and brackish underground reservoirs to a useful resource.

The broader goal of this NSF I-Corps project is to understand the need and challenges for sustainable purification of high salinity water. The team has recently developed a nanophotonics-enabled solar membrane distillation system (NESMD) which has the potential for scalable, modular, off-the-grid desalination. As a part of I-Corps we have conducted customer discovery and market research for high salinity water treatment technologies. The aim was to understand how our technology fits in solving current challenges and what improvements are necessary to address these issues.

We conducted more than 160 interviews with more than 100 in person interviews with people working in Oil & Gas industries, saltwater disposal (SWD) companies, desalination plants and people living in regions with brackish water in the Unites States.

Oil & Gas Industry generates more than 20 billion barrels of produced water in the United States. The salt content of this produced water can vary from low levels to being 10x seawater. The disposal of produced water requires O&G industries to follow government protocols and costs them between 10 cents/bbl to more than $5/bbl depending on salt level, location of the drilling site and availability of disposal methods. Presently, the high salinity produced water is mainly disposed of in saltwater disposal wells which can be either owned by the Oil & Gas companies or managed by saltwater disposal companies. Upon numerous interviews, one outcome is that cost reduction is at the center of profitability for Oil & Gas industries and, unless a new technology can reduce the price they are currently paying to dispose of produced water, the interest in treating produced water differently remains low. One important factor that increases the cost of produced water purification is transportation and infrastructure cost to carry produced water from production to saltwater disposal wells. This explains the location-dependent variability in disposal costs.

After interviewing professionals from saltwater disposal companies, we realized that produced water becomes their liability, upon collecting it from Oil & Gas players. The majority of SWD companies inject produced water in saltwater disposal wells, which are costly to drill and have limited capacity. A technology to purify produced water and make it available for agricultural or human use, would reduce disposal costs and possibly turn purified water in a source of revenue.

Currently, 18,000 desalination plants are operational worldwide to face the increasing demand of fresh water. Most of these desalination plants utilize reverse osmosis (RO) with specially designed membranes to desalinate water. During on-site visits and several interviews, we learned that RO systems typically work at a water recovery rate of 70-80%, meaning that plants typically producing more than 20 million gallons of fresh water per day, also generate more than 5 million gallons of high salinity waste. Similar to Oil & Gas industries, this high salinity waste is mainly transported to saltwater disposal wells or evaporation ponds.  Treating this high salinity waste with an appropriate technology would produce additional fresh water supply and allow the recovery of minerals from the concentrated derived brine.

People living in regions lacking fresh municipal water usually exploit underground water. However, areas with brackish water are common and traditional reverse osmosis membrane cannot purify it effectively. As a result, people in these regions need to buy drinking water from stores. The household plumbing is easily damaged by brackish water and any installed reverse osmosis system would soon become ineffective due to frequent membrane replacement. In conclusion, there is need for a sustainable, low cost water treatment solution for people living in regions where brackish is available without a centralized water purification system. Such solutions would also have broader impact for people in developing countries living in regions with brackish or impure water sources.

Overall, from the interviews we learned that there is a real need for a technology to treat high salinity water to work in areas where traditional reverse osmosis membranes cannot function effectively.
